content.webTitle: When an apostrophe turns into catastrophe | Brief letters

fields.headline: When an apostrophe turns into catastrophe
fields.bodyText: I was a dyslexic child and during the school holidays my mother used to put me through the daily chore of reading out the Country diary as dictation, so I could practise my spelling. Although a lifelong Guardian reader, I have avoided it ever since. On Wednesday morning my eye caught the opening few words, “garrulous gatecrashers” and my spirits sank. Dr Brian O’Callaghan Sonning, Berkshire • I love Kingsley Amis’s response to a challenge about the usefulness of apostrophes: “Those things over there are my husbands.” Three different possible meanings (‘Ignorance’ wins battle over use of apostrophe, 2 December). Bryan Morgan Worksop, Nottinghamshire • A greengrocer’s in Hexham was once memorably (and accurately) described on Look North as the place where “the apostrophe becomes a catastrophe” (Pass notes, G2, 3 December). Chris Southey Durham • I am 87. I still put my socks on while standing because Nancy Banks-Smith wrote that doing so sitting down was a sign of old age (Letters, 3 December). Gordon Ward Stroud, Gloucestershire • Yates’s in Blackpool “was known for its Australian wine and draught beer” (The big picture, 30 November). In 1974 I was there recovering from a motorcycle accident. I had a pair of wooden crutches to get around. Having had my fair share of sherry one evening, I hopped down to the prom and promptly fell into the sea. A B&B room in Blackpool was never so cold.
